title: 110_hr392
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. The Secretary has flexibility in selecting designs for the coins, with inscriptions potentially appearing on the reverse side. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and various territories. The Secretary will select the designs after consulting with relevant authorities. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant authorities, will select designs for quarter dollars representing the District of Columbia and territories. Designs will be reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design selection and approval process will be at the sole discretion of the Secretary, who may also involve District or territorial officials in the process. The Secretary may involve District or territorial officials, artists, engravers, and the public in selecting dignified designs for quarter dollars. Designs cannot include head and shoulders portraits or living persons. The coins minted will be considered numismatic items. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars in uncirculated and proof qualities, with some coins containing 90 percent silver. Coins honoring the District of Columbia and territories will be issued in equal intervals during 2009. The legislation applies to the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Provisions are outlined for the event of statehood or independence for these territories. The legislation applies to various territories including the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The term "territory" is defined for the purposes of the legislation. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on January 23, 2007. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
